title: Intercession of the Saints
intro: Hypothesis: The saints in Heaven pray for people on earth.

evidence.head: The Vision of Onias and Jeremiah
evidence.short: Judas Maccabeus had a vision of the late high priest Onias praying for the Jews, and the prophet Jeremiah giving Judas a sword.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this illustrates the intercession of the saints already in the Old Testament.

Critics argue that this is a vision, so it may not be literally true. Also, 2 Maccabees is not in the Jewish canon of Scripture, so some critics feel it is less authoritative, if at all.

evidence.head: Angels Pray for People
evidence.short: There are several examples of angels interceding for people in the Bible, sometimes by praying themselves, and sometimes by presenting people's prayers to God.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this suggests people in Heaven can also intercede, especially because Jesus says people will be "like the angels in Heaven" at the resurrection, which might mean they can perform many of the same tasks in Heaven.

Critics argue that Jesus is talking specifically about marriage in that passage, so not getting married might be the only thing people will have in common with angels.

evidence.head: Martyrs and the Altar In Heaven
evidence.short: John's vision includes martyrs in Heaven asking God to avenge them.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this shows human saints in Heaven praying to God, and that it would be reasonable to believe that they also pray for those on earth.

Critics caution that this is a vision and may not be literally how things work. Also, the prayers are for vengeance on their own behalf, so it could be a literary device or a symbolic way to express their status as martyrs.
references: Revelation 7:13–15; 8:3–4: https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Revelation%207%3A13%E2%80%9315%3B%208%3A3%E2%80%934&version=NRSVCE (Angels present the prayers of the saints, but this may refer to God's people on earth, rather than those in Heaven.)

evidence.head: Pray for Each Other
evidence.short: Christians are instructed to pray for each other.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that there is no reason to think that those in Heaven would stop following this command.

Critics caution that we don't know what people actually do in Heaven, so this is speculative.

evidence.head: Church Fathers In Support
evidence.short: Several Church Fathers affirm the intercession of the saints.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this shows the belief that saints intercede for those on earth to be widespread early on.

Critics point out that it isn't mentioned all that often, so it may not have been an important belief to combat or an important teaching to deny.
references: Origen (c. 230 AD), On Prayer, Chapter IV: https://tertullian.org/fathers/origen_on_prayer_02_text.htm ("But these pray along with those who genuinely pray—not only the high priest but also the angels (...) and also the souls of the saints already at rest.")

St. Cyprian of Carthage (d. 258 AD), Epistle 56: https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/050656.htm ("Let us relieve burdens and afflictions by mutual love, that if any one of us, by the swiftness of divine condescension, shall go hence the first, our love may continue in the presence of the Lord, and our prayers for our brethren and sisters not cease in the presence of the Father's mercy.")

evidence.head: One Mediator
evidence.short: St. Paul writes to Timothy that there is one God and one mediator, the man Jesus Christ.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this indicates that Jesus is the one who intercedes for us.

Proponents object that Jesus mediates the New Covenant, but St. Paul still instructs us to pray for each other in the same paragraph. Also, the Holy Spirit and angels are said to pray for us as well.
